p: Wiberg et al. reported the formation of Ti(AlH 4) 4 (11.1 wt.% hydrogen content) in 1951 [ 14]. The synthetic route was the metathesis reaction between TiCl 4 and LiAlH 4 in ether at −110 °C [ 14]. Later, in 1975, Kost et al. reported a similar synthesis while using LiAlH 4 and TiBr 4 or TiCl 4. The product was separated from the solution in a filter cooled with dry ice [ 241]. The reported stoichiometries indicted that the metathesis reaction was not completed or that partial substitution of Cl − by [AlH 4] − was achieved [ 241]. Wiberg reported that Ti(AlH 4) 4 was decomposed at −85 °C [ 14]; for its part, Kost reported the evolution of “two g-atom of H per g-atom of Ti” at −70 °C [ 241]. The decomposition of Ti(AlH 4) 4 was proposed as [ 241]: Ti(AlH 4) 4 → TiH 2 + 4AlH 3 + H 2. (67)
